nodes.name: Dataset Structured
nodes.description: This Node creates a DataFrame by reading data from HDFS, HIVE etc. The dataset was defined earlier in Fire by using the Dataset Feature. As a user, you just have to select the Dataset of your interest.
nodes.details:
This Node creates a DataFrame by reading data from HDFS, HIVE etc.

The data has been defined earlier in Fire by using the Dataset Feature. As a user, you just have to select the Dataset of your interest.
nodes.examples:
Dataset Structured Node Example


Scenario:

Let's say you have multiple datasets available in your workflow and you want to select one of them as input for the next node. You can use the Dataset Structured node to choose the desired dataset.

Configuration:

1. **Output Storage Level:** Select the desired storage level for the output DataFrame.
2. **Dataset:** Choose the dataset from the dropdown list.

Output:

The node will output the selected dataset as a DataFrame.

fields.name: comment
fields.value:
A customer is considered "churned" if they made a purchase in a given month but then made no further purchases for the next 90 days.


Monthly Customer Churn Report 

 Of all the customers who were active in a given month, what percentage of them failed to make another purchase in the following 90 days?


Customer Retention Report

ï»¿When we look at all our currently inactive customers, in which month did they make their final purchase, and what was their value?
fields.title: Comment
fields.description: Comments for the Workflow

nodes.name: Monthly Customer Churn Report
nodes.details:
Graph Values Details


This node represents variation between data of various data series in Graphical format.

Multiple numeric columns can be plotted along Y-Coordinate. Only one can be selected along X-Coordinate.

Variation between dataseries is plotted as graph of the selected type such as Line-Chart, Bar-Chart or so on.

Input

  • TITLE :- The title of a graph can be set here.
  • X LABEL :- X-axis label can be set here.
  • Y LABEL :- Y-axis label can be set here.
  • MAX VALUES TO DISPLAY :- The total number of the data points can be selected here.
  • CHART TYPE :- The desired chart can be selected from the drop-down list(Line Chart,Side By Side Bar Chart,Pie Chart,Scatter Chart)
  • CHART COLORS :- The different types of color can be selected for better visualization.
  • IS STREAMING? :- If the graph is stream graph set the option as true else false(by default it is false).
  • X COLUMN :- Select the column for X-axis.
  • Y COLUMNS :- Select the colum for Y-axis.

Output

  • It will plot a graph and will represent the trends between mentioned columns.
  • The different types of a graph can be plotted between specified columns to check the trends.

Types Of Chart

  • Line Chart
  • Side By Side Bar Chart
  • Stack Bar Chart
  • Pie Chart
  • Scatter Chart
  • Dual Line Chart
  • Area Chart

Example

  • A line chart allows us to track the development of several variables at the same time.
  • Scatter plots are used to determine whether or not two variables have a relationship or correlation.
  • The main motive of a stacked bar chart is to compare numeric values between levels of a categorical variable.
nodes.examples:
Example:

Let's say you have a dataset with sales figures for different products over time. You can configure the Graph Values node as follows:

X Column: Date
Y Columns: Sales_ProductA, Sales_ProductB
Chart Type: Line Chart
The node will generate a line chart showing the sales trends for both products over time.

nodes.name: Churn Rate Trend
nodes.description: This node runs the given SQL on the incoming DataFrame
nodes.details:
SQL Details


SQL node receives an input data frame. It creates a temporary table on top of that data frame. It executes the provided SQL in the node on the temporary table.

The resulting data frame of running the SQL is passed on to the next node.
nodes.examples:
SQL Examples


Below are some examples of SQL.

Temporary table name used : tempTable

The schema of the Input Dataframe is : id, price, lotsize, bedrooms, bathrms, stories, driveway, recroom, fullbase, gashw, airco, garagepl, prefarea

find the average price of houses


select avg(price) as avg_price from tempTable


find bedrooms with avg price greater than 10000


select bedrooms, avg_price from
(select bedrooms, avg(price) as avg_price from tempTable group by bedrooms) as temp where avg_price > 10000


details of houses with bedrooms avg price greater than 10000


select tempTable.* , inner_table.avg_price from
(select bedrooms, avg_price from
(select bedrooms, avg(price) as avg_price from tempTable group by bedrooms) as temp where avg_price > 10000) as inner_table
JOIN tempTable ON(inner_table.bedrooms = tempTable.bedrooms)
nodes.hint: Whenever the table is changed, go to InferSchema tab and Infer the Schema

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: tempTable
fields.title: Temp Table
fields.description: Temp Table Name to be used

fields.name: sql
fields.value:
WITH monthly_customers AS (
    -- Step 1: Find all unique customers active in each month
    SELECT
        DATE_TRUNC('month', INV_DT) AS month,
        CUSTOMER_ID
    FROM fire_temp_table
    GROUP BY 1, 2
),
active_customers AS (
    -- Step 2: Count the number of active customers per month
    SELECT
        month,
        COUNT(DISTINCT customer_id) AS Active_Customers
    FROM monthly_customers
    GROUP BY month
),
churned_customers AS (
    -- Step 3: Identify customers who did not return in the next 3 months
    SELECT
        mc.month,
        COUNT(DISTINCT mc.customer_id) AS Customers_Who_Churned
    FROM monthly_customers mc
    LEFT JOIN monthly_customers future
        ON mc.customer_id = future.customer_id
       AND future.month > mc.month
       AND future.month <= mc.month + INTERVAL '3 months'
    WHERE future.customer_id IS NULL
    GROUP BY mc.month
)
-- Step 4: Combine data and filter out incomplete months for an accurate report
SELECT
   DATE_FORMAT(a.month, 'yyyy-MM')  AS Month,
    a.Active_Customers,
    c.Customers_Who_Churned,
    CAST(
        ROUND(c.Customers_Who_Churned * 100.0 / a.Active_Customers, 2)
        AS FLOAT
    ) AS Churn_Rate_Percentage
FROM active_customers a
JOIN churned_customers c ON a.month = c.month -- Use JOIN to automatically filter for months with churn data
WHERE
    -- This is the crucial part: Only include months where a 90-day churn calculation is possible.
    -- It ensures we have a full 3-month window of data after the month being analyzed.
    a.month < DATE_TRUNC('month', (SELECT MAX(INV_DT) FROM fire_temp_table)) - INTERVAL '2 months'
ORDER BY a.month

nodes.name: Print N Rows
nodes.description: Prints the specified number of records in the DataFrame. It is useful for seeing intermediate output
nodes.details:
Print N Rows Node Details


This node is used to print the first N rows from the incoming dataframe.

The Number of rows that needs to be printed can be configured in the node.

Input Parameters

  • OUTPUT STORAGE LEVEL : Keep this as DEFAULT.
  • TITLE : Enter a short description for the type of information being displayed.
  • NUM ROWS TO PRINT : Set an integer value(N) which controls the number of rows to be displayed(Default N=10).
  • DISPLAY DATA TYPE : Shows the output dataframe column datatypes by default.

Output

  • This node can be used to view, analyze and validate the output of the Dataframe.
nodes.examples:
when input 5 in no of rows,it will show first 5 rows of the table as follows

PartID SupplierID PartName

P9271 S798 Part_D
P523 S955 Part_K
P3201 S332 Part_M
P9634 S527 Part_G
P9345 S850 Part_M

nodes.name: Revenue at Risk by Month
nodes.description: This node runs the given SQL on the incoming DataFrame
nodes.details:
SQL Details


SQL node receives an input data frame. It creates a temporary table on top of that data frame. It executes the provided SQL in the node on the temporary table.

The resulting data frame of running the SQL is passed on to the next node.
nodes.examples:
SQL Examples


Below are some examples of SQL.

Temporary table name used : tempTable

The schema of the Input Dataframe is : id, price, lotsize, bedrooms, bathrms, stories, driveway, recroom, fullbase, gashw, airco, garagepl, prefarea

find the average price of houses


select avg(price) as avg_price from tempTable


find bedrooms with avg price greater than 10000


select bedrooms, avg_price from
(select bedrooms, avg(price) as avg_price from tempTable group by bedrooms) as temp where avg_price > 10000


details of houses with bedrooms avg price greater than 10000


select tempTable.* , inner_table.avg_price from
(select bedrooms, avg_price from
(select bedrooms, avg(price) as avg_price from tempTable group by bedrooms) as temp where avg_price > 10000) as inner_table
JOIN tempTable ON(inner_table.bedrooms = tempTable.bedrooms)
nodes.hint: Whenever the table is changed, go to InferSchema tab and Infer the Schema

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: tempTable
fields.title: Temp Table
fields.description: Temp Table Name to be used

fields.name: sql
fields.value:
-- Step 1: For each customer, find their last purchase month and calculate their average sales from their last 3 months of activity.
WITH customer_sales_history AS (
    SELECT
        CUSTOMER_ID,
        -- Calculate average sales based on the customer's OWN last 3 months of purchases.
        SUM(
            CASE
                -- Only include sales from the last 3 months relative to the customer's personal max invoice date.
                WHEN INV_DT >= ADD_MONTHS( (SELECT MAX(t2.INV_DT) FROM fire_temp_table t2 WHERE t2.CUSTOMER_ID = t1.CUSTOMER_ID), -2)
                THEN GROSS
                ELSE 0
            END
        ) / 3 AS avg_customer_spend,
        -- Find the month of their very last purchase.
        DATE_TRUNC('month', MAX(INV_DT)) AS last_purchase_month
    FROM
        fire_temp_table t1
    GROUP BY
        CUSTOMER_ID
),
-- Step 2: Get the most recent month in the entire dataset to use as our reference point.
max_date_info AS (
    SELECT DATE_TRUNC('month', MAX(INV_DT)) AS max_month FROM fire_temp_table
)
-- Step 3: Sum the average spending for customers who are now considered "at risk".
SELECT
    DATE_FORMAT(csh.last_purchase_month, 'yyyy-MM') AS last_purchase_month,
    SUM(csh.avg_customer_spend) AS revenue_at_risk
FROM
    customer_sales_history csh
WHERE
    -- An "at risk" cohort is one whose last purchase was more than 3 months ago relative to our dataset's latest date.
    csh.last_purchase_month < ADD_MONTHS((SELECT max_month FROM max_date_info), -2)
GROUP BY
    csh.last_purchase_month
HAVING
    SUM(csh.avg_customer_spend) > 0 -- Only show cohorts with actual revenue at risk.
ORDER BY
    csh.last_purchase_month;

nodes.name: Customer Retention Report
nodes.description: This node runs the given SQL on the incoming DataFrame
nodes.details:
SQL Details


SQL node receives an input data frame. It creates a temporary table on top of that data frame. It executes the provided SQL in the node on the temporary table.

The resulting data frame of running the SQL is passed on to the next node.
nodes.examples:
SQL Examples


Below are some examples of SQL.

Temporary table name used : tempTable

The schema of the Input Dataframe is : id, price, lotsize, bedrooms, bathrms, stories, driveway, recroom, fullbase, gashw, airco, garagepl, prefarea

find the average price of houses


select avg(price) as avg_price from tempTable


find bedrooms with avg price greater than 10000


select bedrooms, avg_price from
(select bedrooms, avg(price) as avg_price from tempTable group by bedrooms) as temp where avg_price > 10000


details of houses with bedrooms avg price greater than 10000


select tempTable.* , inner_table.avg_price from
(select bedrooms, avg_price from
(select bedrooms, avg(price) as avg_price from tempTable group by bedrooms) as temp where avg_price > 10000) as inner_table
JOIN tempTable ON(inner_table.bedrooms = tempTable.bedrooms)
nodes.hint: Whenever the table is changed, go to InferSchema tab and Infer the Schema

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: tempTable
fields.title: Temp Table
fields.description: Temp Table Name to be used

fields.name: sql
fields.value:
-- =================================================================================
-- Comprehensive Customer Retention Report
-- This report identifies cohorts of customers who have become inactive ("at risk")
-- and quantifies the financial impact.
--
-- Definitions:
-- - At-Risk Customer: A customer who has not made a purchase in over 90 days.
-- - Cohort Month: The last month a customer made a purchase before becoming inactive.
-- =================================================================================

-- Step 1: For each customer, calculate their average monthly spend over their last 3 active months
-- and identify the month of their final purchase.
WITH customer_sales_history AS (
    SELECT
        CUSTOMER_ID,
        -- Calculate average sales based on the customer's OWN last 3 months of purchases.
        SUM(
            CASE
                WHEN INV_DT >= ADD_MONTHS((SELECT MAX(t2.INV_DT) FROM fire_temp_table t2 WHERE t2.CUSTOMER_ID = t1.CUSTOMER_ID), -2)
                THEN GROSS
                ELSE 0
            END
        ) / 3 AS avg_customer_spend,
        -- Find the month of their very last purchase.
        DATE_TRUNC('month', MAX(INV_DT)) AS last_purchase_month
    FROM
        fire_temp_table t1
    GROUP BY
        CUSTOMER_ID
),

-- Step 2: Get the most recent month in the entire dataset to use as our reference point for identifying "at-risk" cohorts.
max_date_info AS (
    SELECT DATE_TRUNC('month', MAX(INV_DT)) AS max_month FROM fire_temp_table
)

-- Step 3: Aggregate the data by cohort to build the final report.
SELECT
   DATE_FORMAT(csh.last_purchase_month, 'yyyy-MM') AS Cohort_Month_of_Last_Purchase,

    -- Column 1: Count the number of customers in the at-risk cohort.
    COUNT(DISTINCT csh.CUSTOMER_ID) AS Number_of_At_Risk_Customers,

    -- Column 2: Sum the total monthly revenue lost from this cohort.
    ROUND(SUM(csh.avg_customer_spend), 2) AS Total_Monthly_Revenue_at_Risk,

    -- Column 3: Calculate the average value of each lost customer in this cohort.
    ROUND(
        SUM(csh.avg_customer_spend) / COUNT(DISTINCT csh.CUSTOMER_ID),
        2
    ) AS Avg_Revenue_per_Lost_Customer

FROM
    customer_sales_history csh
WHERE
    -- Filter for "at-risk" cohorts: those whose last purchase was more than 3 months ago
    -- relative to the latest data available.
    csh.last_purchase_month < ADD_MONTHS((SELECT max_month FROM max_date_info), -2)
GROUP BY
    csh.last_purchase_month
HAVING
    SUM(csh.avg_customer_spend) > 0 -- Exclude cohorts with zero financial impact.
ORDER BY
    csh.last_purchase_month;

nodes.name: Revenue at Risk by Customer Cohort
nodes.details:
Bar Chart Node


This node creates a bar chart to visualize numerical data. It allows you to compare values across different categories or time periods .
You can rename columns,sort the categories and make changes in labels as needed for your visualisation
nodes.examples:
Bar Chart Node Example


Scenario:

Let's say you have a dataset with sales figures for different products over time. You can use the Bar Chart node to visualize the sales trends for each product.

Configuration:

1. **Color Range:** Enable or disable color-coding of the bars.
2. **X Column:** Select the column to be used as the X-axis (e.g., product name or time period).
3. **Sort on X Column:** Sort the bars based on the X-axis values.
4. **Y Columns:** Select one or more columns to be displayed on the Y-axis (e.g., sales figures).
5. **Y Sort Column:** Sort the Y-axis values.
6. **Rename Y Columns:** Rename the Y-axis columns for better clarity.

Output:

The node will generate a bar chart visualizing the selected data. You can customize the chart's appearance using various options, such as color palette, chart title, and axis labels.

Use Cases:

  • Sales Analysis:Visualize sales trends over time or across different products.
  • Financial Analysis:Compare financial metrics for different time periods or business units.
  • Market Research: Analyze market share and customer preferences.
